Posts.Content: Jan 27, 2009 05:22AM sherry64 wrote: Keep busy and clean the house, stock up on groceries, pay the bills, catch up on laundry and just get things ready so you can take it easy for a while once you get home.  Time will fly and you'll be home and recovering before you know it.   Sherry
Posts.Title: OK on the outside, YIKES on inside! ghety Mykidsmom

Posts.Content: Jan 14, 2009 08:58AM sherry64 wrote: I also had SNBs on both sides.  My surgeon recommended this.  Both LCIS and DCIS were incidental findings for me and we wanted to make sure no other incidental findings were hiding anywhere. Speaking of SNB, my surgeon went up through my mast incisions to get to the nodes so I didn't have any additional incisions for the SNBs.  I think this made recovery much easier.  Is this the usual approach?
Posts.Title: Has anyone done sentinal node biopsy on prophylactic side? samiam40 Binney4

Posts.Content: May 13, 2009 09:25AM sherry64 wrote: I'm sorry about your struggles. I really had very little pain following my bilateral mx and only took Advil (600mg in the early days).  I was uncomfortable but not in pain. Is it possible you won't need the strong stuff?  Regarding telling your surgeon,  I think you should be up front.  She really needs all of your info to take care of you and keep you safe.  Good luck. Sherry
Posts.Title: To tell or not. Need Advice Lursa5 nancypat

Posts.Content: Dec 5, 2008 12:42PM sherry64 wrote: First, I would absolutely call your surgeon's office and at least speak to his nurse and voice your concerns.  Second, I'm four days post bilateral mast with expanders and my scars are about 3" long and pinched together in the front of my breasts where the nipples were.  It's like if you wrapped dough around an apple and pinched the dough closed at the top.  I also wonder if this is a normal scar.  They appear to be healing well but I don't know why they looked so pinched. Call now before the office closes for the weekend.  That's what your surgeon and his staff are there for.  Good luck. Sherry
Posts.Title: Is my mx scar normal? digger BethNY

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2009 01:25PM sherry64 wrote: Nerves are cut during surgery and there is some pulling and tugging of skin and tissue during the procedure. The tingling and sensitivity are annoying but probably normal.  In any case, I would definitely mention any concerns to your surgeon.

Anne-I'm glad you've finished your five years.  Yes, I would think my risk has been greatly reduced with the masts.   mocame-Did you have DCIS or LCIS close to the skin?  Although I haven't actually seen my path report yet, it is my impression that no additional DCIS was found but  plenty of LCIS remains.  So I'm hoping they won't need to take additional tissue and like you, I won't need any rads or Tamox.

Posts.Title: EKG pad & adhesive tape residue partridge Estepp

Posts.Content: Feb 2, 2009 08:07AM sherry64 wrote: Francine-Don't forget that eating healthy with lots of protein will help the vac get you healed.  I also consume a lot of vitamin C as I think that helps wound healing also.  Another good thing about the vac is I think it helps prevent infection because it keeps the wound sealed so nasties can't get in as easily.  Hopefully you'll find each day gets easier plus it gets exciting when the nurses measure the wound and tell you it's getting smaller!  Sherry
Posts.Title: Post Mastectomy problem- Dying skin crusader1 NotVeryBrave

Posts.Content: Jan 24, 2009 01:55PM sherry64 wrote: My PS thinks moist is best.  I have an opening about 1" by 1/2" where the incision has split.  He debrided it last week in the office and instructed me to keep it covered by gauze coated with a little neosporin.  I change the gauze three times a day.  When the gauze is removed it's actually good if it pulls off bits of old tissue as this makes room for healthy tissue to grow. Sort of like at home debridement. So now I have an opening with glistening pink/white tissue but no more dead tissue.  I'm not sure how the sides are going to come together but he told me to expect it to heal just fine.  I also worry about something happening to the expander because of this.  Another worry is that the skin will be thin once the opening heals and cause expander problems.  Plus, I haven't had a fill since surgery and like Digger, I'm desperate for fills so I can get this over with. I did read on the web that the basics of wound care were to debride dead tissue so healthy tissue could thrive and keep the wound moist/covered.  Also eat lots of protein and nutrient dense fruits and veggies and lots Vit. C.  I'm glad we wound challenged, delayed fill girls found each other. I think we all have similar concerns.   Francine, I'm so sorry you're losing your expander.  I do think the vac will help close your wound more quickly. Best wishes on your surgery. Sherry
Posts.Title: Post Mastectomy problem- Dying skin crusader1 NotVeryBrave

Posts.Content: sherry64 wrote: Happy Holidays!  This morning after showering I noticed bloody fluid running down my breast from my incision.  Not a lot and now it's where I can just blot it off with a tissue.  But I'm a little concerned because I haven't had any leakage whatsoever since surgery 3 weeks ago.  I know a seroma is a possibility or maybe some of the scab just came off too early.  I had a skin sparing mast so the incisions are gathered and pinched together at the front of each breast.  Oh, and I overdid it yesterday with shopping, driving kids around, etc.  Has anyone had this happen so far out from surgery? Sherry  12/01/08 Bilateral mast with tissue expanders; LCIS in margins Dx 10/9/2008, DCIS, Stage 0, Grade 1, 0/4 nodes Log in to post a reply

Good luck with your decision.
Posts.Title: Having Bilat Mast--SNB Just on DCIS Side or Both Sides? ASL momof3kidz

Posts.Content: Dec 9, 2008 08:23AM sherry64 wrote: As an update, my surgeon wants me to see the oncologist again as well as a radiation oncologist.  I plan to follow his advice but I can't imagine radiation would be recommended for LCIS.  The oncologist could recommend Tamox but she is pretty conservative and might just suggest close monitoring. mocame-If they wanted better margins, I bet it was DCIS near the edge. I was lucky that my small amount of DCIS was removed during a biopsy.
Posts.Title: LCIS in margins after bilateral mast sherry64 karen9516

Posts.Content: Jan 27, 2009 11:18PM sherry64 wrote: You aren't very far out from surgery so you should expect to feel tired and out of sorts.  I've definitely had my throat sore after surgery, I guess due to intubation.  Do you think your pain could be managed with Advil?  I try to not take pain meds and my PS suggested three Advil every four hours which worked fine and I had no problems with constipation. The chores you're doing involve bending down and using your arms. My advice would be to take it super easy, rest and talk to your surgeon about your concerns at your post op appt.  If you're really concerned, especially with the diabetes, I would give them a call. Time should work wonders but you have to take it easy. Sherry

Sherry

Posts.Content: sherry64 wrote: Hi.  I just posted this question on the LCIS Forum but also wanted to check here.  On Monday I had bilateral SNB's and mastectomies with expanders.  Nodes were negative.  Just heard back from surgeon's asst. (surgeon is out of town) and DCIS appears to have been successfully removed in previous biopsy and nothing worse was found.  But LCIS is all over the margins in the left breast tissue.  I meet with the surgeon on Monday but I'm now worried he may suggest Tamoxifen since LCIS is definitely in the remaining breast cells.  One reason I chose mast was to avoid Tamoxifen (and rads).  Am I still going to end up with close monitoring and Tamoxifen even though I gave up my breasts??? 12/01/08 Bilateral mast with tissue expanders; LCIS in margins Dx 10/9/2008, DCIS, Stage 0, Grade 1, 0/4 nodes Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: sherry64 wrote: I currently have tissue expanders and am scheduled for exchange in two weeks.  A few weeks ago I started using stretch mark cream and noticed lumpy areas including a small, movable lump, all over my left tissue expander.  These areas do not appear to be part of the TE.  Saw BS and ultrasound didn't show anything.  I am wondering if it's possible I still have some fibrocystic tissue left after the mast. BS is thinking these areas should be checked out during the exchange.  Anyone else develop lumpy bumpies on chest wall over TEs? Posts.Title: Continued fibrocystic changes AFTER mastectomy? sherry64 phoenixsmom

Posts.Content: Nov 7, 2008 10:43PM sherry64 wrote: I am 44 and was recently diagnosed with extensive bilateral LCIS and right sided multifocal DCIS following bilateral biopsies.  I am scheduled for a bilateral mast with SNB and recon in a few weeks.  My surgeon recommended this approach while my onc recommended re-excision, rads and tamox.  But the onc also mentioned that I would certainly be in for more surgery in the future as stuff showed up on MRIs, etc.  I seriously wanted to avoid rads and tamox and have the best chance for good healing and a successful reconstruction.  The bilateral mast was an obvious choice for me and I didn't think twice about it.   I just want to be done with it and hopefully my path reports will cooperate and I will never be in the 2% recurrance group.

Sherry
